title: Male rage hits the multinplex: what Joker tells us about 'incel' culture
text:
Like Taxi Driver and Fight Club before it, Joker has been seen as a cry for help from disenfranchised, angry men – incels. But does that make it dangerous? asks Sam Parker

In the blistering opening essay of her best-selling collection Trick Mirror: Reflections On Self Delusion, the New Yorker writer Jia Tolentino argues that, in the beginning, the internet was a hopeful and peaceful place. Early message boards and websites, clunky in their interface but pure in their intentions, sprouted like green shoots in a new, fertile earth.

It was a place where people with niche interests and identities huddled together for solace and communicated according to the civility that still governed "real life"...
description: Like Taxi Driver and Fight Club before it, Joker has been seen as a cry for help from disenfranchised, angry men – incels.
